meanings.definition: A person or thing that is of higher moral or intellectual value
meanings.sent1: The teacher was a sublimer in the eyes of her students, always guiding them with wisdom and kindness.
meanings.sent2: The philosopher's ideas were considered sublimer than those of his peers.
meanings.sent3: The wise old owl was jokingly referred to as the sublimer of the forest creatures.
meanings.sent4: Her selfless actions made her a sublimer in the community, a beacon of light in dark times.
meanings.sent5: The painting of the majestic mountain was a true sublimer, capturing its grandeur perfectly.

meanings.definition: To make something more noble or exalted
meanings.sent1: She hoped her speech would sublimer the importance of kindness and compassion.
meanings.sent2: The artist used gold leaf to sublimer the beauty of the ancient statue.
meanings.sent3: The chef's secret ingredient seemed to sublimer the flavor of the dish to heavenly levels.
meanings.sent4: His words had the power to sublimer even the simplest of ideas into profound truths.
meanings.sent5: The melody of the violin seemed to sublimer the emotions of the listeners, bringing tears to their eyes.

meanings.definition: To elevate or uplift in a spiritual or emotional sense
meanings.sent1: The music had a magical quality that seemed to sublimer the soul to a higher plane.
meanings.sent2: The sunset's beauty never failed to sublimer her spirits after a long day.
meanings.sent3: The unexpected kindness of a stranger can sublimer even the gloomiest of days.
meanings.sent4: Her words of encouragement always had the power to sublimer his mood and outlook on life.
meanings.sent5: The breathtaking view from the mountaintop seemed to sublimer his sense of wonder and awe at the world.
